title: Done deal: Affinity investors ready for high Velocity payday
text:
Affinity's exit at Velocity on Friday came as its dealmakers were also stitching up a $1.3 billion-odd deal to sell Ticketek owner TEG to US private equity group Silver Lake.

Interestingly it is understood that deal, should it complete as scheduled, would see Affinity return 2.6-times its original investment, which means another healthy payday for the manager and its investors.

Affinity's numbers show why big superannuation and sovereign wealth funds are re-thinking private equity allocations. The industry pin-up, Australia's Future Fund which has returned 10.4 per cent a year over the past decade, had $25.7 billion in private equity as at June 30 for a 15.8 per cent allocation.

The twin exits will no doubt have Affinity's local team looking to re-stock its investment portfolio. Velocity and TEG were the firm's two biggest Australian investments.

Meanwhile two of Affinity's rivals, KKR and TPG Capital, are progressing plans to list their online real estate classifieds business on the ASX boards.

As Street Talk reported on Monday, KKR and TPG-backed PropertyGuru will seek to raise up to $380.2 million for its initial public offering via the sale of 84.5 million to 93.3 million securities at $3.70 to $4.50 each.

The price represented 9 to 10.9 times forecast revenue for the 2020 calendar year.

The deal valued PropertyGuru at $1 billion to $1.22 billion on an enterprise value basis and would see its trading on the ASX with a market capitalisation worth $1.16 billion to $1.36 billion.

Securities sold at the IPO would represent a 30.1 per cent to 32.2 per cent stake in the company, according to terms sent to potential buyers.
description: Affinity Equity Partners has made more than 3½ times its money investing in Velocity Frequent Flyer.
